The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in mathematics. The most promising approach is to use the category of Hilbert spaces and continuous linear operators as a foundation. This approach has been developed by many authors, including von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. However, the foundations are not completely understood. In this paper, we provide a set of axioms that guarantee that the category of Hilbert spaces and continuous linear operators is equivalent to a category of mathematical objects that are purely categorical in nature. This resolves a long-standing question about the foundations of quantum theory.

The Myxozoa are a diverse group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. To gain insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite, we compared the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species to the transcriptome and genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides a unique resource for understanding the evolution of the Myxozoa and the origin of parasitism. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade host immune responses is a common strategy used by pathogens to cause disease and spread. In this study, we describe a mechanism of viral antagonism in which SARS-CoV-2 hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to impair nuclear import of cargo proteins and prevent the induction of IFN-stimulated genes. Our results uncover a previously unknown mechanism of viral antagonism that could be targeted to develop new therapeutic strategies to combat COVID-19. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet this demand. This will be difficult to achieve because of the increasing frequency of extreme weather events, such as droughts and heat waves. Here, we show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in many of the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries as the Earth warms. This will make it more difficult for countries to produce enough food for their own people and for export. The instability of global grain trade and international grain prices will increase, and the risk of food insecurity will rise. These results highlight the need for increased investments in breeding maize varieties that are more heat tolerant.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in savanna ecosystems. However, the extent to which species partition food-plant species is largely unknown because of the difficulty of species-level identification with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers, and dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, dietary composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the importance of using DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for species-level identification in future studies of large mammal diets. The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the crisis on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

The accumulation of plastic debris in the ocean has become a major environmental concern. However, the magnitude and the fate of this pollution are still open questions. Using data from the Malaspina 2010 circumnavigation, regional surveys, and previously published reports, we show a worldwide distribution of plastic on the surface of the open ocean, mostly accumulating in the convergence zones of each of the five subtropical gyres with comparable density. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface was estimated to be on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is a fundamental characteristic of all organisms. In humans, the ability to reproduce is often taken for granted, but in other species, it is a limiting factor in population growth. In this study, we use a comparative approach to understand the factors that increase reproductive output. We find that domestication and all forms of allocare correlate with increased fertility. All forms of provisioning correlate with larger litters without compromising offspring size. The greatest increase we observe in reproductive power is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproductive output and the factors that limit it. (Less)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn in the striatum of α-synuclein transgenic mice, a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of α-syn oligomers and neuroprotection. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in MSA. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept of the ability of VX-765 to mitigate α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in synucleinopathy models. This study also provides a rationale for the use of VX-765 in patients with MSA. This study opens the door to the development of VX-765 as a therapeutic agent for other synucleinopathies

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling vascular function and is the first line of defense against infection and injury. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform a variety of functions. To perform these functions, the endothelium must be able to receive and integrate information from multiple sources. Here, we show that the endothelium is connected in a network that is small-world, meaning that the network is both locally and globally efficient. The network is also highly dynamic, with short path lengths and a high degree of synchronizability. These findings reveal that the endothelium is designed to be both efficient and robust in the integration of information. This is important for the control of cardiovascular function. The endothelium is the target of many drugs and therapies, and understanding the design of the endothelium will help to improve the design of these therapies.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. The COVIDcast API is our attempt to provide open access to data that can be used to monitor the pandemic and inform public health and research. The API provides access to many signals of COVID activity, including traditional public health surveillance signals (cases, deaths, and hospitalizations) and many auxiliary indicators of COVID activity, such as signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data and software are available to the public through the API and accompanying R and Python packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). A state-dependent crystallographic study of KcsA-T75A proves that, on activation, the selectivity filter transitions from a nonconductive and deep C-type inactivated conformation to a conductive one. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a deeper understanding of the allosteric communication between the selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a role in human health and disease. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is not fully understood, and there is a need to identify the molecules that regulate the composition of the microbiome. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. We find that anaerobic fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, including antibiotics, antimicrobials, and other bioactive compounds. These results support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi are a source of natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. This study provides a foundation for future research on the role of anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome.

Anxiety is a common feature of many psychiatric disorders, including social anxiety disorder. However, the underlying mechanisms remain largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety influences social dominance in rats and identify an important role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We also demonstrate that pharmacological manipulation of mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens can alter social rank. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. However, the design space is restricted by the limited knowledge of material properties and the complexity of the structures. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize composite structures with multiple material phases to achieve arbitrary and extreme responses under large deformations. The synthesized structures are digitally designed with irregular material distributions and seamless material transitions. The responses are physically realized in experiments, which are highly complex and unachievable by a single material. The hemoglobin (Hb) system is a major regulator of oxygen transport in the human body. The Hb system is regulated by a complex network of transcription factors and RNA-binding proteins. Here we demonstrate that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of Hb expression in human erythroid tissues. IGF2BP1 is expressed in adult bone marrow and is downregulated in fetal liver. In erythroid tissues, IGF2BP1 expression is developmental upregulated, resulting in a reversal of the adult Hb expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This study provides a mechanism for chronoregulation of Hb expression in humans. The results also suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies. Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. Despite recent advances in cancer treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to therapy and succumb to the disease. In this study, we identified a mechanism of cancer cell resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We found that this resistance is mediated by activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which in turn activates sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1) and monounsaturated fatty acid production. We also found that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction. These findings suggest that combination of ferroptosis induction with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway inhibition may be a promising strategy for cancer treatment. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral–associated birds, but failed to reverse the decline of older-forest–associated birds. The NWFP is a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy, and our findings have important implications for the future of forest management in the United States.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a long and expensive process, which is why it is essential to use computational approaches to keep pace with the evolution of pathogens. In this work, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics that are active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. We show that our design strategy is successful in identifying compounds that are active against resistant pathogens and that are more active than telithromycin, the only approved acylide antibiotic. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work provides a proof of concept for the use of computational approaches in the rational design of new antibiotics. The developed approach can be used to identify new compounds for other antibiotic classes. The compounds identified in this work can be used to develop new antibiotics to fight antibiotic resistance.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This practice has been shown to suppress melatonin, phase-shift the biological clock, and reduce sleep quality. However, the impact of these devices on the circadian clock and sleep in the following day has not been studied. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device suppresses melatonin and reduces sleep quality, and that this effect is greater than when reading a printed book. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmune diseases has been controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. In addition, we show that CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice has opposing effects on different autoimmune models. Thus, although CTLA-4–deficient mice had more severe collagen-induced arthritis, they were protected against peptide-induced experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Phylogenomic analyses resolved controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of these genes in their genomes. We propose that these genes enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation antibody drugs against SARS-CoV-2 variants. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The apolipoprotein E (APOE) gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) susceptibility. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and APOE4 is the most strongly associated isoform. APOE is also highly expressed in astrocytes, a major cell type in the central nervous system. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis, whereas APOE4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in the brain, which may be due to defective astrocytic phagocytosis. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective astrocytic phagocytosis, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a molecular mechanism for the role of APOE in AD pathogenesis. They also suggest a potential therapeutic target for AD treatment. The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is 1,200 km in radius and has a density of 12.0 g/cm3. It is the densest solid in the solar system. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of a liquid iron core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. In this paper, we demonstrate that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process, which is different from the crystallization of the outer core. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. This work provides a new perspective on the origin of the inner core. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the drug is illegal, it is widely available, and its use is increasing. The drug is also associated with a range of negative consequences, including impaired cognition, violence, and motor vehicle accidents. The present study provides evidence that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine) is reduced in marijuana abusers, which might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. The findings have implications for understanding the neurobiological basis of marijuana abuse and for developing effective treatments.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending it are poorly understood. Here, we use a large-scale, integrative modeling approach to reveal how the human brain processes language. We find that the most powerful machine learning models predict nearly 100% of the explainable variance in neural responses to sentences. Models’ fits to the data generalize across datasets and imaging modalities, and model architecture appears to contribute to neural fit. These results provide computationally explicit evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the brain’s language machinery may be more similar to a modern computer than previously thought. This approach may prove useful for understanding other complex cognitive and neural processes. (Show more)

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that this instability is not due to the lack of stability, but rather to the lack of algorithms that can compute stable networks. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where no algorithm can compute a stable neural network with a given accuracy, even if we allow for an arbitrarily large number of training samples. This result is a step toward understanding the limits of deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. This paper discusses a classic experiment published 45 years ago that has been cited more than 1,000 times in the past 10 y. Despite its critical design flaws, it has become a canonical study in the field of social psychology. We argue that this is a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research. In hindsight, this is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in quantum mechanics. The interplay between them is still poorly understood, and the entanglement dynamics is a key ingredient in this context. In this work, we provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit for a paradigmatic model, the Heisenberg chain. Our results are based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle descriptions, which allow us to compute the entanglement dynamics in a closed form. We check our result for the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain and find perfect agreement with numerical simulations. Our work provides a powerful tool for the study of the entanglement dynamics in a wide range of systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been devastating, and there is an urgent need for a safe and effective vaccine. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is highly attenuated and induces robust immune responses. In a relevant hamster model, COVI-VAC is protective at a single intranasal dose. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. This study provides a promising candidate for the global fight against COVID-19. (Show more)

Plague, caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis, is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. Today, most human plague cases are bubonic, caused by spillover of infected fleas from rodent epizootics, or pneumonic, caused by inhalation of infectious droplets. However, little is known about the historical spread of plague in Europe during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries), including the Black Death, which led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. Here, we describe a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides a better understanding of the history of plague in Europe and may help to prevent future outbreaks. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of brain size is a key topic in comparative neurobiology. However, it is often difficult to disentangle the effects of brain size and the number of neurons on cognitive ability. This study uses the largest dataset of its kind to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuronal numbers in amniotes. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. Amniote brain evolution is characterized by the following four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred independently with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endotherm lineages. The other two major increases in the number of neurons happened in core land birds and anthropoid primates, which are two groups known for their cognitive prowess.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled. The actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family is the main regulator of actin filament disassembly. It is a key player in many cellular processes, including cell motility, cell division, and cell death. However, how it does so in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques, coupled to microfluidics, to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that mechanical stress has no effect on ADF/cofilin binding, but dramatically enhances severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. We propose that it is a general mechanism that is used by other ADF/cofilin-related proteins to sever filament networks in cells. This mechanism could be a target for the development of new drugs. This work provides a mechanistic explanation of how cells control the disassembly of actin filaments. It also provides a new approach to control the disassembly

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often consumed in excess, and it may play a role in the epidemic of obesity and type 2 diabetes. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also suggest that the brain may be a target for interventions aimed at reducing fructose consumption and the risk of obesity and type 2 diabetes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the effects of fructose versus glucose on brain, hormone, and appetitive responses to food cues and food-approach behavior. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The admixture happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar, which is a unique case in the world. It will help to understand the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, which is well established in laboratory experiments. However, the results of previous experiments are controversial, and some have suggested that emotional contagion does not occur in the real world. Our results suggest that this controversy may be due to the fact that previous experiments have not considered the possibility that emotional contagion may occur outside of in-person interaction between individuals. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and the design of interventions to reduce the spread of negative emotions.

The vast majority of RNA in the cell is not protein-coding, and noncoding RNAs have a wide range of functions. One of the most common modifications in coding regions is pseudouridine (Ψ), which is found in 10–20% of uridine nucleotides. We show that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can have a modest impact on translation. We also show that Ψ can increase the rate of near-cognate amino acid addition to a codon, and that the presence of Ψ can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions can have subtle effects on the translation of mRNAs. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes in older age, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to the effects of factors such as prosperity, depressive symptoms, and social support. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. This study provides evidence for the importance of a sense of purpose in sustaining well-being and health in old age. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known and widely cited example of the “island syndrome,” in which the absence of size-related ecological competition leads to the evolution of larger body sizes. However, the mechanisms driving this evolution have not been tested quantitatively. Here, we use a model of the energetic constraints imposed by the aquatic environment to show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a direct consequence of the aquatic environment.

Rhinovirus, the common cold virus, replicates more robustly at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. To understand the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth, we compared the transcriptional response of primary mouse airway epithelial cells infected with rhinovirus at 33 °C vs. 37 °C. We found that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus exhibited a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C, which correlated with significantly higher expression levels of type I and type III IFN genes and ISGs at 37 °C. Temperature-dependent IFN induction in response to rhinovirus was dependent on the MAVS protein, a key signaling adaptor of the RIG-I–like receptors (RLRs). Stimulation of primary airway cells with the synthetic RLR ligand poly I:C led to greater IFN induction at 37 °C relative to 33 °C at early time points poststimulation and to a sustained increase in the induction of ISGs at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. The ability to sense and respond to environmental cues is a fundamental property of all living organisms. In this work, we demonstrate that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface adhesin type IV pili to detect surfaces. This sensing mechanism is mediated by the type IV pilus-associated chemotaxis system, which regulates the production of cAMP and the expression of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. The mechanochemical model proposed here suggests that the type IV pilus-associated chemotaxis system measures the mechanical activity of the surface adhesin type IV pili, thereby promoting long-term surface attachment that can stimulate additional virulence and biofilm-inducing pathways. This study thus provides a mechanistic understanding of how bacteria sense surfaces and highlights the importance of type IV pili in bacterial surface sensing. These findings also provide a framework for the design of new antibacterial strategies. (Show more)

The importance of agricultural pesticides in surface water has been underestimated due to a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. This study provides a global metaanalysis of 838 peer-reviewed studies that evaluates the presence of particularly toxic agricultural insecticides in surface water. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This study is a first step toward a better understanding of the global pesticide problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in animals has raised concerns about the potential for spillback into wildlife and the reemergence of the virus. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer during the winter months, when human cases are declining. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of this trend and the problems that are being created. We also propose solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) hypothesis has been the focus of extensive research. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation and progression of AD is still controversial. Here, we show that soluble Aβ species, which are not deposited in the brain, are the most toxic amyloid species and are responsible for the initiation of an inflammatory response in neurons. This neuron-specific inflammatory response may precede the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles, and may be a critical component in the AD pathogenesis. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a primary target for therapeutic intervention. This study provides a new perspective on the AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species and is a main source of protein in the human diet. However, for thousands of years exploitation of chickens was confined to symbolic and social domains such as cockfighting. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. The folding of proteins is a complex process that is not yet understood. The results reported here provide evidence that the folding of the large maltose binding protein is composed of distinct steps. The steps are not sequential but rather are part of a single process that is interrupted by the formation of a native-like intermediate. The intermediate is a transient structure that is not the final state of folding. The intermediate is not the only structure that is important for folding. The results suggest that the intermediate is a common structure in the folding of large proteins.

The accumulation of RNA molecules capped with dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be critical for the survival of bacteria. However, the mechanism by which this capping occurs is still unknown. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing this cap is a pyrophosphohydrolase, RppH, which preferentially removes Np4-capped RNAs over their tri- and diphosphorylated counterparts. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although the immune response is essential for the resolution of infection, it can also be detrimental, leading to organ failure and death. In this study, we demonstrate that arginine, a major amino acid, is depleted in sepsis and that this depletion is associated with the expansion of myeloid-derived suppressor cells and regulatory T cells. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is more effective than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation and in decreasing the expansion of immunosuppressive cells. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (PsycINFO Database Record

The biomass of the biosphere is a key quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly marine. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a quantitative view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and are a step toward a better understanding of the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature, such as earthquakes, avalanches, or forest fires, where a system is in a critical state and the dynamics are scale-free. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of the occurrence times of events. The simplest model of SOC is the so-called sandpile model, which is a discrete-time dynamical system on a lattice. In this paper, we study a continuous version of the sandpile model, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We describe the model and its relation to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

We also show that diamond can be demetallized, without phonon instability, under tensile strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. The role of plant immune peptides in defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the structural basis for their antifungal activity is not well understood. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide from the nodules of the model legume Medicago truncatula. This peptide is highly dynamic and has a unique structure with one α-helix and one β-sheet stabilized by two disulfide bonds. The antifungal activity of this peptide is due to its ability to bind to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in germlings of the fungal pathogen Botrytis cinerea. The antifungal activity of this peptide is also demonstrated in planta. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of plant immune peptides and opens up the possibility of developing this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction, and the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. We combined semiquantitative proteomics with sex-specific isotopic labeling to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Multiple seminal fluid proteins initially associate with sperm, but most become undetectable after sperm are stored. Female-derived proteins also begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Female-derived proteins that associate with sperm are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (PsycINFO Database Record

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered efforts to understand the impact of viruses on human health. This study overcomes this obstacle, and provides a resource for the community to study the impact of viruses on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of high-resolution and simultaneous observations of diurnal aerosol loading and cloud microphysical properties. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to conduct a case study over Beijing. The observations show that increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius, consistent with expectations. However, the aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. The isotopic record of the Earth’s oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes derived from light-requiring prokaryotic and eukaryotic phototrophs having widely separated fossil-based divergence ages. The ancestral environmental temperatures thereby determined for these photic-zone organisms––shown in modern taxa to correlate strongly with NDK thermostability––are inferred to reflect ancient surface-environment paleotemperatures. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Malaria is a devastating disease that affects millions of people each year. The parasite, Plasmodium, invades the red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle. The malaria parasite exploits a number of host cell receptors and signaling pathways to facilitate invasion. Here, we show that the malaria parasite exploits the host cell’s own receptors and signaling pathways to alter the physical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This study provides a new perspective on the invasion process and opens up the possibility that the malaria parasite is not simply exploiting a receptor, but is instead altering the physical properties of the host cell to facilitate invasion. This study could lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies to combat this disease. (Show more)

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the impact of low humidity on host response to influenza infection and disease outcome. The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of syntactic relations between words, but there is no direct evidence for this hypothesis. Here, we show that the brain responds to each successive word in a sentence with a sudden increase in gamma power, which decreases when words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is consistent with the hypothesis that the brain builds a hierarchy of nested phrases. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. The merge operation is a fundamental building block of language processing, and our results suggest that it is implemented by the brain in a bottom-up or left-corner fashion. This approach may be more efficient than the current top-down or right-corner parsing strategies used by language models. (PsycINFO Database Record

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that regulates a wide range of processes, including cell proliferation, differentiation, and migration. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to the canonical Wnt pathway. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This study provides a deeper understanding of the mechanism of redundant gene pairs and their regulation. It also provides a basis for the development of new therapeutic strategies for diseases caused by the disruption of the canonical Wnt pathway.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. This effect is blocked by dopamine receptor antagonists, suggesting that dopamine is involved. However, the dopamine neurons that project to LH and the downstream circuitry that mediates LH stimulation-induced eating have not been characterized. Here we show that stimulation of LH neurons causes eating in a circuit that involves dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and dopamine neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region. Lesions of these neurons block eating induced by LH stimulation. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work provides a framework for understanding the mechanisms of overeating and obesity. (PsycINFO Database Record

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to engineer nitrogen fixation in plants is a key goal for sustainable agriculture. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-bacterial signaling system that allows the control of nitrogen fixation in a cereal crop. This system is based on the production of a bacterial signal by the cereal host, which is then transferred to the bacterium, allowing the cereal to control the expression of the nitrogenase genes in the bacterium. This work also provides a proof of concept for the use of transkingdom signaling in the control of nitrogen fixation in other organisms. This approach could be used to control the activity of other nitrogen-fixing enzymes, such as those involved in ammonia assimilation, and could also be extended to other organisms, such as cyanobacteria, which fix atmospheric nitrogen. The Amazon is losing forest cover at an alarming rate. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are used to incentivize community-based monitoring, but the effectiveness of these programs is unknown. We study a community monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was randomly assigned to 39 of 76 communities. Our results suggest that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Data from monitoring records and community surveys provide evidence about how the program may affect forest outcomes. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are diverse, but all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which allows the spider to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This study provides a unique example of outsourcing and supersizing of hearing in animals. It also provides a new perspective on the evolution of hearing in animals.

The climate and health impacts of anthropogenic aerosols and greenhouse gases are difficult to disentangle. We use a global model to estimate the climate and health outcomes of a phaseout of fossil fuels, indicating the potential benefits of a rapid phaseout. We show that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. Aerosols affect the hydrologic cycle, contributing to water and food security. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. The model results provide a quantitative assessment of the benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels. The results are relevant to the Paris Climate Agreement and the Sustainable Development Goals. The role of the ALK receptor in the development of neural crest-derived tissues has been studied in a variety of species. However, the ligand(s) that activate ALK in vivo are still unknown. Here, we show that zebrafish ALKals can activate ALK/LTK receptors in vitro and in vivo. We also show that zebrafish ALKals are required for the development of iridophores, a pigment cell type derived from the neural crest. Our results provide evidence that ALK/LTK receptors are activated by secreted ALKALs in vivo. These findings may help to understand the role of ALK/LTK receptors in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. The emergence of plague as a devastating disease in human history is a well-documented event, but the details of its early evolution remain poorly understood. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from Eurasia dating to the Late Neolithic and Early Bronze Age. Our results reveal a single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This information is critical for understanding the origins of plague and its impact on human history. (Less)

The management of agricultural systems has a profound impact on soil organic carbon (SOC) storage. However, the extent to which these impacts are positive or negative, and the mechanisms underlying them, remain highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage in Mollisols, but the extent to which this is due to the effects of these practices on soil microbial traits is not well understood. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses from wildlife to humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify risk factors for spillover and developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The top 12 ranked viruses were known zoonotic viruses, including SARS-CoV-2. Several newly detected viruses ranked higher than known zoonotic viruses. Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is a key trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms underlying this adaptation are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work cumulatively identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides a framework for understanding the evolution of nectar color in plants and vertebrates. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Roman Empire and the early Middle Ages is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 450 and 650 AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, functional variants indicate that they also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Examination of the panel of functional loci also revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. These findings provide insights into the origin of MERS-CoV and the potential of HKU4 and HKU5 to cause human infections. They also provide a basis for the development of vaccines

We used a cloud-based metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) platform to investigate a large periurban hospital in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers in Cambodia. This study demonstrates the feasibility of mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings and the potential to detect undifferentiated febrile illness caused by a variety of pathogens. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. One of the most important proteins involved in the replication of the lagging strand is DNA polymerase δ (pol δ). In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of pol δ. We found that pol δ maintains a loose association with the PCNA sliding clamp while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the structure and function of pol δ and opens up new avenues for the development of therapeutic strategies to treat diseases associated with pol δ dysfunction. The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, the evolution of proteins has been studied, but the evolution of RNA replication has not. Here, we use in vitro evolution to improve the activity and generality of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. The polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a foundation for the study of the origin of life. (Show more)

This paper introduces a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. The results also suggest that physical improvements in neighborhoods are more likely to occur in areas with higher concentrations of college-educated adults and that the physical appearance of neighborhoods is more likely to be improved by the presence of other physically attractive neighborhoods. These results are important for urban planning and for the study of urban change.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, may be a potential treatment for COVID-19. The results of this study provide a reference for the clinical treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability of fungi to sequester copper in the form of isocyanide-containing metabolites suggests a role for these compounds in the regulation of copper homeostasis and in the control of interactions with competing microbes. The existence of the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in several filamentous fungi suggests that this pathway is a source of fungal natural products that can impact copper homeostasis and the ability of fungi to interact with other microbes. This study provides a framework for the study of the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis and the control of interactions with competing microbes. (Show more)

The discovery of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is significant because it is a high-temperature (>870 °C) SiO2 polymorph that is rare on Earth. The tridymitic mudstone has ∼40 wt.% crystalline and ∼60 wt.% X-ray amorphous material and a bulk composition with ∼74 wt.% SiO2. Plagioclase (∼17 wt.% of bulk sample), tridymite (∼14 wt.%), sanidine (∼3 wt.%), cation-deficient magnetite (∼3 wt.%), cristobalite (∼2 wt.%), and anhydrite (∼1 wt.%) are the mudstone crystalline minerals. Amorphous material is silica-rich (∼39 wt.% opal-A and/or high-SiO2 glass and opal-CT), volatile-bearing (16 wt.% mixed cation sulfates, phosphates, and chlorides−perchlorates−chlorates), and has minor TiO2 and Fe2O3T oxides (∼5 wt.%). Frost damage is a major threat to plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. The geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of these frost events are poorly understood. Here, we analyze the geographic distribution of late-spring frosts and the resistance strategies of woody species to infer trees’ adaptations for minimizing frost damage to their leaves. We find that areas in which late-spring frosts are common, such as eastern North America, harbor tree species with cautious (late-leafing) leaf-out strategies. Areas in which late-spring frosts used to be unlikely, such as broad-leaved forests and shrublands in Europe and Asia, instead harbor opportunistic tree species (quickly reacting to warming air temperatures). Given species’ innate resistance strategies, we estimate that ∼35% of the European and ∼26% of the Asian temperate forest area, but only ∼10% of the North American, will experience increasing late-frost damage in the future. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, Th17 cells display substantial developmental plasticity, such that some progeny of Th17 cell precursors retain a predominantly IL-17A+ phenotype, whereas others extinguish IL-17 expression and acquire expression of IFN-γ, giving rise to “Th1-like” cells. It remains unclear what role these subsets play in inflammatory bowel disease. Using a Th17 transfer model of colitis, we found that IFN-γ–deficient Th17 cells retained an IL-17A+ phenotype and were unable to induce colitis in recipients. Development of disease required the transition of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells and was contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Th17 cells could provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes and different clinical courses. The disease is also difficult to model in animal models, limiting the ability to test potential therapies. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. These cells can be used to study disease mechanisms and to test potential therapies. This method will be useful for ALS research and for other neurodegenerative diseases. The method is also applicable to other cell types, such as microglia, which are also involved in neurodegenerative diseases. This method will be useful for research and drug discovery.

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors plays a critical role in the transmission of infectious agents to vertebrate hosts. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vectors are poorly understood. Here, we show that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the gut microbiota of its vector, the blacklegged tick, I. scapularis, to more efficiently infect the tick. We demonstrate that the pathogen induces the tick to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the tick microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix, a barrier that protects the gut from infection. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vectors. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of life. However, the early history of the short-tailed bird group is poorly understood because of the limited known diversity of early branching pygostylians. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding the evolution of the avian body plan. The presence of a fused scapulocoracoid in adult individuals independently evolved in Jinguofortisidae and Confuciusornithiformes may relate to an accelerated osteogenesis during chondrogenesis and likely formed through the heterochronic process of peramorphosis by which these basal taxa retain the scapulocoracoid of the nonavian theropod ancestors with the addition of flight-related modifications. With wings having a low aspect ratio and wing loading, Jinguofortis may have been adapted particularly to dense forest environments.
