The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of the atmosphere. In this paper, we show that the atmosphere plays an important role in the climate system. We show that the atmosphere is a major contributor to the climate sensitivity of the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color in response to environmental cues. In this study, we describe a mechanism that allows animals to change their color in a physiological way. We found that the color of anurans (frogs and toads) is determined by a group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a molecule that is normally found in the blood. This discovery provides a molecular basis for the evolution of color change in vertebrates. It also shows that the serpin superfamily, the largest group of protease inhibitors, has a remarkable functional diversification. Our results have important implications for understanding the evolution of color change in vertebrates and the function of the serpin superfamily.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The ability of breast cancer cells to form tumorigenic cells, which are referred to as cancer stem cells (CSCs), is a major obstacle to successful treatment. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the expression of the pluripotency factor NANOG and the breast cancer stem cell (BCSC) phenotype. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the hypoxia-inducible factors HIF-1α and HIF-2α, which in turn are activated by hypoxia. Thus, ALKBH5 expression is a key mechanism by which hypoxia promotes the BCSC phenotype. These findings provide a mechanism for how hypoxia may promote the development of CSCs in breast cancer. This may have important implications for the treatment of breast cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record

The parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was so thin that it was almost tissue-thin. The source of this parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the animal origin of parchment from the earliest pocket Bibles

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical to understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds in China. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.

RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including IBD. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for neutralizing antibodies and vaccines. We use cryo-electron microscopy to determine the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor-binding domain of ACE2. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein is associated with a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can alter the carbon cycle. However, the effects of climate change on fire regimes are uncertain, and the role of human ignitions and suppression is not well understood. We quantify the effects of climate change and human demography on fire activity and the carbon cycle, using a coupled climate–fire–carbon cycle model. We find that climate change and human demography can both warm and cool the global fire regime, but that human demography tends to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. This potentially reduces warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. Our study highlights the importance of human ignitions and suppression in driving future fire regimes.

The symbiotic associations between animals and microbes are among the most ancient and widespread in nature. The mutualism between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is a classic example. The squid provides the symbiont with a constant supply of chitin, a polymer that is catabolized only at night, when the squid is active. This study shows that the chitin catabolism is required for the acidification of the squid’s symbiotic crypts, which enhances the activity of the symbiont. This work suggests that the chitin catabolism may be a general mechanism for the regulation of the activities of symbionts associated with epithelial tissues. This mechanism may be used by other animal hosts to control the activities of their symbionts. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify latent patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use a sparse representation of an embedding space to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as latent discourse atoms. We can infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). The NVDRS summarizes violent death incidents with structured variables and unstructured narratives. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. Motivated by known patterns in suicide and homicide by gender and recent research on gender biases in semantic space, we identify the gender bias of our topics (e.g., a topic about pain medication is feminine). We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. The Black Death, the most devastating epidemic in human history, originated in Asia and arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. The disease was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This study shows that the Black Death was reintroduced into Europe repeatedly, via the same trade routes, over a period of four centuries. Our results provide evidence for the importance of the ancient Silk Road system in the spread of the plague across Eurasia. This study also provides evidence for the importance of climate variability in the spread of the plague. (Less)

The sea star (asteroid) wasting disease (SSWD) is a devastating disease that has caused the mass mortality of at least 20 species of asteroids on the Pacific Coast of North America. The disease is characterized by rapid degradation of the animal. We show that the disease is caused by a virus. The virus is transmitted by the sea star’s natural predators, the crown-of-thorns starfish (Acanthaster planci). The virus is also present in the plankton and sediments, suggesting that it is spread by the movement of water and sediment. The virus is also present in museum specimens of asteroids from 1942, suggesting that it has been present on the Pacific Coast for at least 72 y.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a highly heterogeneous disease, and the identification of specific targets for therapy is a major challenge. In this study, we show that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We also show that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. Furthermore, we demonstrate that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling is effective in suppressing the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also provide a proof-of-concept for the use of antibodies as a treatment for AML. This approach could be extended to other targets that are expressed on leukemic stem cells but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, revealing a common Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution of Europeans and the Middle East to Madagascar, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia. In addition, we found that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar, which is essential to understand the history of this unique island. This article is protected by copyright. Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with the membrane-associated aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, GlpD, and increases dehydrogenase activity. The protein also interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress genes cadA and galE. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions of the RNA compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to regulate metabolism. (Show more)

Language processing involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. This ability is thought to be supported by elevated neural activity. However, other work has suggested that short-term synaptic facilitation can also contribute to memory. Here we propose a model of memory that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability that occur in neurons during normal processing. Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community. However, despite decades of research, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. This information is critical to improving our understanding of the global carbon cycle and the potential for further increases in global temperatures.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most fundamental events in the evolution of life. The molecular mechanisms underlying this transition are still poorly understood. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water security. The contribution of anthropogenic climate change to this prolonged rainfall deficit has previously been evaluated through observations and climate models. However, model adequacy and insufficient horizontal resolution make it difficult to precisely quantify the changing likelihood of extreme droughts, given the small regional scale. Here, we use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear SSA rainfall deficits in past and future decades. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. (Bacterio)chlorophylls have an isocyclic fifth ring, the formation of which has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase ASK1, which is a key regulator of neuroinflammation. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation. ASK1 deficiency in T cells and dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE severity. Microglia-specific ASK1 deletion was achieved using a CX3CR1CreER system, and we found that ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits in California were more than twice as likely to yield drought years if they occurred when conditions were warm. We find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. In addition, the probability that precipitation deficits co-occur with warm conditions and the probability that precipitation deficits produce drought have both increased. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder that is caused by multiple genetic and environmental factors. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This work offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. They also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+) entry channel, the CRAC channel, is a key regulator of cellular functions, including gene expression, cell growth and differentiation, and Ca2+ homeostasis. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 (p.R304W) associated with Stormorken syndrome, and in ORAI1 (p.P245L), associated with a Stormorken-like syndrome of congenital miosis and tubular aggregate myopathy but without hematological abnormalities. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease. In this study, we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that protein aggregates spread in a non–cell-autonomous manner, and that this spreading is associated with the internalization and accumulation of aggregates within other neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for studying the mechanisms underlying the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is a key metabolic intermediate. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. Cancer cells have high SHMT activity, and thus high demand for the one-carbon unit. We have developed a series of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT, and have shown that they are effective in vitro and in vivo. We have also shown that one-carbon donor formate is a potent inhibitor of SHMT, and that this effect is reversed in cancer cells. Thus, formate is a promising therapeutic for cancer. Finally, we have shown that DLBCL cells are uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand, and thus are uniquely dependent upon SHMT inhibition for survival. These results suggest that SHMT inhibition is a promising therapeutic for DLBCL. Collectively, these results provide a foundation for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a therapeutic for cancer. This work is a step toward the development of a cancer-specific one-carbon unit inhibitor.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. The inclusion bodies are composed of a variety of proteins that do not share obvious characteristics other than coaggregation. However, recent evidence from other neurodegenerative disorders suggests that disease-affected biochemical pathways can be characterized by the presence of proteins that are supersaturated, with cellular concentrations significantly greater than their solubilities. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions of mutant SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The results are expected to be of interest to researchers in many areas, including atom optics, quantum optics, and many-body physics. The earliest known angiosperms are aquatic plants that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water. The discovery of Montsechia, a new species of early angiosperm, opens the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, and it is important to understand the evolution of the most recent common ancestor of all viruses. Here we present the most ancient viral sequences of parvovirus B19 (B19V) from ancient human remains. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya. We also find that the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising, and it is rising quickly. This is a well-established fact. However, the rate of sea level rise is not constant. In fact, it is accelerating. This acceleration is a result of the melting of glaciers and ice sheets and the expansion of the ocean as it warms. We use satellite altimeter data to estimate the acceleration of global mean sea level over the last 25 y and find that it is 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2. This acceleration is consistent with the climate models used to estimate future sea level rise. The acceleration is also consistent with the IPCC AR5 projections.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950 than for those born before 1950. This pattern is seen across measures of pain, including self-report, medical records, and the presence of opioids. The increase in pain is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. Instead, it is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If this trend continues, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate of the disease highlights the need for effective treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. The symbiotic associations between animals and microbes are among the most ancient and widespread in nature. The mutualism between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is a classic example. The squid provides the symbiont with a constant supply of chitin, a polymer that is catabolized only at night, when the squid is active. This study shows that the chitin catabolism is required for the acidification of the symbiotic crypts, which in turn enhances the activity of the symbiont. This work provides a mechanistic explanation for the timing of the chitin delivery and the acidification, and suggests that the provision of specific nutrients may be a general strategy for the maintenance of symbiosis. This paper describes a series of experiments and field tests that tested whether teachers’ mindsets about discipline could be changed. The experiments showed that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. The field tests showed that this change in mindset was associated with a 50% reduction in student suspensions. This work has implications for the future of American schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental problems. The food choices of the population have a major impact on this system, and it is therefore important to understand how to encourage people to make more sustainable dietary choices. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering environment can have a significant impact on meal selection. This approach could be used in other settings to encourage more sustainable dietary choices.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. This study provides a systems-level view of how six of the most prominent oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion. The surfaceome and glycoproteome are both modified by oncogenes, and the changes are coordinated in a cell-type specific manner. These studies provide a foundation for understanding the biology of the surfaceome and glycoproteome, and for developing surface-based drug and biomarker discovery. The data also suggest that the surfaceome and glycoproteome are important targets for cancer therapy.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout rates. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic.

The SARS-CoV-2 virus has caused a global pandemic, with a high mortality rate and a rapid spread. The molecular basis for the severity of the disease is unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides a molecular basis for the unique properties of SARS-CoV-2 and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is associated with increased expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that the up-regulated expression of CRFR1 and AQP4 in hypoxic cortex is mediated by CRF acting on CRFR1, and that this up-regulation of AQP4 contributes to edema via AQP4. These results provide insights into the mechanisms of hypoxic cerebral edema and suggest that CRFR1 agonists may be useful in the treatment of this disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The problem is that we have “cherry picked” a large dataset and the tools for “cherry picking” are now very sophisticated. The bar for declaring significant the associations that we see must be set higher. We show how to do this in a principled way.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). In coordination with endogenous FOXC2 in fibroblasts, transduced ETV2 elicits expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. The receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) ALK and LTK are important in the development of the nervous system and the immune system. In addition, they are oncogenic drivers in a variety of cancers. In this study, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function of ALK and LTK and to characterize in vivo links between ALK and LTK with their ligands. We show that zebrafish deficient in the ligands of ALK and LTK have a severe defect in the development of iridophores, which are specialized cells in the skin that produce the color of the fish. These results establish a physiological link between ALK and LTK and demonstrate that particular ligands activate LTK in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a foundation for understanding the role of ALK and LTK in the development of the nervous system and the immune system. It also provides a foundation for understanding the role of ALK and LTK in cancer. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder that is associated with insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. Although the role of STING in insulin resistance has been well established, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, using global and β-cell–specific knockout mouse models, we revealed that STING deficiency in β-cells but not in peripheral tissues causes T2D. Moreover, STING deficiency in β-cells impairs glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. These findings establish pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study also provides a potential therapeutic target for T2D. (Less)

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The viral genome is segmented into eight RNA fragments, which is a unique feature of this virus. The packaging of the viral genome is a highly regulated process, which is essential for the production of infectious virions. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with the disturbed flow in the blood vessels. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. In this study, we found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by the disturbed flow is critical for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion formation. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow-induced atherogenesis and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. Wildfire is a natural process that has been a part of the Earth system for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen dramatically in the United States in recent decades. Climate change has likely played a role in the increase in wildfire activity, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Actions to reduce the risk of human-caused wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a method for monitoring the physical appearance of neighborhoods over time and may be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in the future.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We estimate the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques, allowing for characterization of the disease progression. We also assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. In the case of favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, we predict a dose of 150 mg/kg given twice a day initiated at the time of infection can reduce the peak median viral load by ∼3 logs and shorten the time to undetectable median viral load by ∼2 d. These results provide insights into the disease progression and the potential effect of antiviral treatment, which may be useful for the design of a treatment strategy. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including global warming, overfishing, and pollution. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, leading to the functional loss of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This work also highlights the importance of considering the metabolic interactions between the host and its symbionts in the interpretation of the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its environmental conditions. The intestinal epithelium is a barrier to the environment and a hub for communication with the microbiome. In this study, we investigate the consequences of tumorigenesis on the microbiome and the microbiome on tumorigenesis. We show that upon loss of BMP signaling, tumors lead to aberrant activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, followed by intestinal barrier dysfunction and commensal imbalance. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. We find that inhibiting JNK signaling or depletion of the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismic lifespan extension. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides insights into the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is not universal. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that ROR1 enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, we found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record

The start of accelerated deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere (SH) is a key event in the history of the Earth system, but the cause is still debated. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions at 17.7 ka led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn caused a poleward shift in the SH westerlies and a rapid advance of the Southern Hemisphere ice sheets. This is the first time that a volcanic eruption has been linked to deglaciation, and it provides a unique opportunity to understand the role of stratospheric ozone changes in the Earth system. This study also demonstrates the value of high-resolution chemical records in ice cores to understand past climate changes. (Show more)

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that inland fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the importance of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. Our results highlight the need for improved management of inland fisheries, particularly in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. This approach can help ensure that the benefits of fisheries are sustained for future generations.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a key feature of the adult nervous system. In mammals, however, the CNS is incapable of regenerating after injury, and the ability to regenerate in the PNS is limited. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in the C. elegans nervous system that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of genes that control regeneration in the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study suggests that the ability to regenerate in the adult nervous system is more widespread than previously thought.

The process of recombination is central to the evolution of genomes. In this work, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is concentrated in hotspots, interspersed with cold regions. The hotspots are more concentrated in the promoter regions of genes than in the promoters of other organisms, and the gene-proximal polarity of recombination is also conserved in positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9–knockout mice. These results provide a detailed view of the distribution of recombination across a genome, and suggest that the ancient mechanisms of recombination initiation described here in Mimulus may reflect conserved eukaryotic processes. The resting brain is a complex system, with a large number of interacting networks. The identification of these networks is a major challenge in neuroscience. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. In healthy subjects, the dominant metabolic RSN was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. The dominant RSN was deactivated during task performance, whereas the subordinate RSNs were activated. These results provide a direct measure of the organization of the brain in health and disease. This approach can be used to identify the mechanisms underlying the development of disease-related patterns. This information can be used to develop new therapeutic strategies.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for efficient translation and is found on all nuclear-encoded mRNAs. Here we describe a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA. We show that NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. NAD-RNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because NAD-RNA is also found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. This 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. The discovery of this second 5′ modification of mRNA opens up new possibilities for the regulation of gene expression. (Show more)

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) showed that intensive glucose control can prevent the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. However, the mechanisms underlying this effect are not fully understood. Here we show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood monocytes persist for several years during the Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study, a long-term follow-up of the DCCT. These epigenetic differences are associated with glycemia and may explain the metabolic memory effect. This study supports an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. These findings may also have implications for the study of other epigenetic mechanisms involved in the pathogenesis of diabetes complications. (PsycINFO Database Record

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The mechanisms underlying the development of this disorder are not fully understood. In this study, we found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. (PsycINFO Database Record

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit flavor is not understood. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce the diverse set of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor. (Show more)

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in the context of global warming. Here we use high-throughput experiments to show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. We found that more diverse communities were required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress, and that this effect was driven by changes in species’ thermal tolerance curves. Our results highlight the importance of considering the effects of global warming in the context of biodiversity loss, and the need to consider the thermal tolerance of species in the design of experiments. This will be critical for predicting the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-running behavior in an open field. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be essential for spatial navigation, are anatomically segregated from other cell types, and that they exhibit strong coupling among themselves but weaker links to other cell types. These results provide a detailed view of the MEC’s functional architecture and help to elucidate the mechanisms underlying navigation. The portable two-photon microscope developed in this study may be used to study the neural basis of behavior in freely moving animals in other contexts. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of environmental and developmental signals. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not required for flowering of the host plant in a host–parasite interaction. Instead, FTs are able to move from the host to the parasite, where they are able to induce flowering. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also illustrates the importance of FTs in interplant communication. Understanding the mechanisms of interplant communication is important for the development of strategies to control plant diseases. (Show more)

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing cells of the substantia nigra. The disease is associated with a loss of dopamine-containing neurons and a reduction in the activity of dopamine-producing neurons. The mechanisms underlying these changes are not fully understood. Here we describe a previously unrecognized form of nigral neuron–neuron communication that is likely to be disrupted in Parkinson’s disease. We show that dopamine-producing neurons are connected to other neurons in the substantia nigra by a bouquet-like structure that contains striosomes, the dopamine-producing neurons’ principal source of input. The striosome–dendron bouquets are likely to be critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease. This work provides a new perspective on the organization of the dopamine system in the brain. (Show more)

We all feel connected to others, but how do we know when we’re feeling connected to someone? We conducted a series of experiments to understand how people feel connected to others. We found that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust predictor of how connected people feel. This effect is driven by the speed with which people respond to each other, rather than by the speed with which they respond to the other person. Finally, we show that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for heart rate control and are characterized by unique electrophysiological properties. SAN function is regulated by multiple mechanisms, including the Ca2+ stores of the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR). Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is selectively expressed in SANCs and plays a critical role in the regulation of SAN function. STIM1 regulates Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs by influencing the activity of store-operated Ca2+ entry, L-type Ca2+ current, and Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. This study provides insights into the mechanisms underlying SAN function and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. In this study, we found that Si pretreatment increased rice resistance against the rice leaffolder in wild-type plants but not in two RNAi lines that were silenced for jasmonate (JA) biosynthesis and perception genes. This interaction between Si and JA in defense against insect herbivores was associated with priming of JA-mediated defense responses and promotion of JA accumulation. These results suggest that Si may be used as a biocontrol agent to protect plants against insect herbivores. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still poorly understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, an enzyme involved in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages and that it is essential for the expression of proinflammatory cytokines. Our results demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism and of the macrophage lipidome. These findings may have important implications for the understanding of the role of ether lipids in the regulation of macrophage function. They may also have implications for the treatment of phenylketonuria, a disease caused by a deficiency of tetrahydrobiopterin. Finally, they may have implications for the treatment of inflammatory diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

Language processing involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. This ability is thought to be supported by elevated neural activity. However, other work has suggested that short-term synaptic facilitation can also contribute to memory. Here we propose a model of memory that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability that occur in neurons during normal processing. We show that these changes in neuronal excitability can be used to store information in a dynamic memory register. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language. It also provides a framework for understanding the neural basis of language processing.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenging task due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Here, we report a systematic assessment of DNA nanostructures for their ability to deliver siRNAs across the cell wall and into plant cells. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are the key design parameters for the delivery of siRNAs across the cell wall and the corresponding gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. The world’s largest lakes are often viewed as “self-cleaning,” but this is not always the case. In this study, we show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to large lakes, especially in nearshore areas. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small watersheds, which are often overlooked in current monitoring and regulatory efforts. This approach could help to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

The study of chemical reactions in the presence of external work sources is a central theme in the field of chemical thermodynamics. In this article, we study the dynamics of a chemical network in the presence of a rare, external work source. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the external work source. This work may be of interest to researchers in the fields of chemical thermodynamics, chemical reaction dynamics, and chemical reaction engineering.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab encephalitis is associated with changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We use a dynamic causal model of the cortical microcircuit to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain the EEG paroxysms in patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that these changes render microcircuitry critically susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms when these key parameters are changed, even though the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also provide a framework for understanding the effects of other types of encephalitis on cortical microcircuitry and the associated paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This framework may also be applicable to other forms of epilepsy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of our understanding of the Earth system. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood because of the difficulty in identifying and quantifying these events. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that this event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon and to an increase in nutrient fluxes. These results provide insights into the Earth system response to abrupt climate change. (Less)

The palm oil industry is a major driver of tropical deforestation, and many countries and corporations have made commitments to reduce this impact. Certification is the most common tool used to meet these commitments, and the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely adopted certification scheme. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has been unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the world’s leading producer of palm oil. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. The exocyst complex is a multisubunit complex that is essential for the final steps of exocytosis. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In plants, the exocyst complex is involved in several processes, such as vacuolar trafficking. However, the regulation of these processes is not fully understood. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. The study also offers a potential explanation for the evolutionarily conserved role of the exocyst complex in regulating several processes. (Show more)

The genetic basis of sex determination is a key component of the evolution of sexual dimorphism. In many vertebrates, sex determination is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, these alleles can interact to produce more than two genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two alleles interact to produce four possible sex classes. We find that multiple alleles can produce modular variation in morphological and behavioral traits, and that the evolution of a new sex determination allele can create additional axes of variation for varied traits. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Understanding the genetic basis of sex determination is critical for the study of sex-related traits and the evolution of sexual dimorphism. (Show more)

The retina is challenged by accumulation of bisretinoids, which are oxidized and degraded by reactive oxygen species and lipofuscin. We show that the chelator deferiprone decreases the oxidation and degradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light and reduces the loss of photoreceptor cells in a mouse model of retinal degeneration. These findings suggest that Fe levels in the retina impact the stability of the bisretinoid A2E and that Fe chelation may be a therapeutic approach to protect the retina from photoreceptor degeneration. This work also provides evidence that the bisretinoid A2E is a target of the Fenton chemistry products. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that this is not the case in the case of siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians that use tentilla (tentacle side branches armed with nematocysts) exclusively for prey capture. We show that siphonophore specialists can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type have directly evolved into specialists on other prey types. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also help build a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution. This is important for understanding the functioning of ecosystems.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. The fossil record for the hominin hand between 800,000 and 1.8 My old is sparse, and the oldest hominin hand fossils are fragmentary. Here we report the discovery of a hand fossil from the Middle Pleistocene that preserves a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this feature and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study highlights the importance of the study of early hominin hand fossils and the need for more of these fossils to be discovered. (Less)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is a key metabolic intermediate. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. Cancer cells have high SHMT activity, and thus high demand for the one-carbon unit. We have developed a series of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT, and have shown that they are effective in vitro and in vivo. We have also shown that one-carbon donor formate is a potent inhibitor of SHMT, and that it is a particularly effective inhibitor of cancer cells. However, formate is not a physiological substrate for SHMT, and thus the use of formate as a substrate is a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells. Thus, formate can be used to target cancer cells. This is a potentially important metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells. This work is a step toward the development of a therapeutic strategy for cancer.

The importance of forests in improving people’s diets is not widely recognized. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase fruit and vegetable consumption and vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using causal inference methods to understand the effects of deforestation on people’s diets. This is the first study to our knowledge that uses causal inference methods to understand the effects of deforestation on people’s diets. The results of this study have implications for understanding the effects of deforestation on people’s diets in other settings.

The mechanization of agriculture has greatly increased the capacity of farm machinery, allowing for higher yields and food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
